teaching_points: EF 40% indicates moderate LV systolic dysfunction (HFrEF - heart failure with reduced ejection fraction)
Preload, afterload, and contractility determine cardiac output and stroke volume
Patients with HFrEF are exquisitely sensitive to acute increases in afterload
Previous MI reduces contractile reserve and increases perioperative MACE risk
Myocardial oxygen supply-demand balance critical in CAD patients
Frank-Starling mechanism: increased preload improves stroke volume until plateau
High RCRI score: CAD + high-risk surgery = elevated perioperative cardiac event risk
Previous MI is RCRI risk factor for major adverse cardiac events (MACE)
Multiple cardiac medications indicate significant cardiac disease burden
Beta-blockers and statins should be continued perioperatively
Functional capacity assessment critical (METs < 4 indicates poor reserve)
Maintain coronary perfusion pressure (CPP = DBP - LVEDP)
Avoid tachycardia (decreases diastolic filling time and coronary perfusion)
Goal heart rate 60-80 to optimize myocardial oxygen balance
Arterial line essential for beat-to-beat BP monitoring
Consider PA catheter or TEE for severe LV dysfunction
CPB considerations: anticoagulation, hypothermia, hemodilution

anesthetic_considerations: Etomidate or midazolam/fentanyl induction to preserve hemodynamics
High-dose opioid technique (fentanyl 10-20 mcg/kg or sufentanil 2-5 mcg/kg)
Maintain preload (euvolemia critical)
Minimize afterload increases (treat hypertension promptly)
Support contractility if needed (inotropes available)
Full anticoagulation for CPB (heparin 300-400 units/kg, target ACT >480 sec)
Cardioplegia for myocardial protection during cross-clamp
ICU admission postoperative with mechanical ventilation initially

teaching_points: Mitral valve apparatus includes annulus, leaflets, chordae tendineae, and papillary muscles
Atrial fibrillation commonly associated with mitral valve disease and LA enlargement
Loss of atrial kick reduces cardiac output by 15-20% (especially critical in diastolic dysfunction)
Chronic mitral regurgitation causes LA dilation and volume overload
CHF history indicates chronic hemodynamic compromise and reduced cardiac reserve
Warfarin anticoagulation for AFib increases bleeding risk - requires reversal before surgery
TEE essential for valve assessment: severity of regurgitation, valve morphology, LA size
INR must be normalized before cardiac surgery (typically <1.5)
Vitamin K, FFP, or PCC for warfarin reversal
AFib increases stroke risk - bridge anticoagulation considerations
Assess pulmonary hypertension secondary to chronic mitral disease
Mitral regurgitation: maintain higher heart rate (80-100) and reduce afterload
Avoid bradycardia and increases in SVR (worsens regurgitant fraction)
After valve replacement: heart tolerates higher afterload, avoid tachycardia
TEE confirms adequate valve function post-repair/replacement
CPB for valve replacement - longer cross-clamp time than CABG alone
Risk of heart block post-MVR (proximity to AV node)

anesthetic_considerations: Reverse warfarin preoperatively (INR <1.5)
Hemodynamically stable induction (etomidate or midazolam/fentanyl)
High-dose opioid technique
Preoperatively: reduce afterload (SVR), maintain forward flow
Postoperatively: new hemodynamic goals after valve replacement
Treat AFib with rate control (beta-blockers, digoxin)
Full anticoagulation for CPB
Pacemaker availability (risk of AV node injury during MVR)
ICU postoperative with mechanical ventilation

teaching_points: Aortic stenosis causes pressure-overload hypertrophy and concentric LV hypertrophy
Low EF in AS indicates severe disease with poor prognosis (decompensated state)
Hypertrophied LV has increased oxygen demand and diastolic dysfunction
Loss of atrial kick is poorly tolerated in AS (diastolic filling critical)
Fixed stroke volume in severe AS - cardiac output depends on heart rate
Sudden afterload reduction can cause cardiovascular collapse in severe AS
Heart failure with diabetes = very high risk (ASA IV)
Diuretic dependence indicates volume overload and decompensated CHF
Optimize volume status preoperatively (may need diuresis)
Severe AS triad: angina, syncope, heart failure (worst prognosis with HF)
Valve area <0.8 cm² or mean gradient >40 mmHg = severe AS
Hemodynamic goals: full preload, slow heart rate (60-70), maintain afterload, sinus rhythm
Avoid hypotension at all costs (coronary perfusion depends on DBP)
Treat hypotension with phenylephrine (pure alpha agonist maintains SVR)
Avoid tachycardia (reduces diastolic filling time in stiff LV)
Have phenylephrine infusion prepared before induction
Consider arterial line before induction for severe AS
Post-valve replacement: different hemodynamics, LV hypertrophy regresses over time

anesthetic_considerations: Arterial line placement awake or with sedation before induction
Phenylephrine infusion ready before induction
Slow, controlled induction (etomidate preferred for hemodynamic stability)
High-dose opioid technique
Avoid sudden decreases in SVR (careful with volatile agents)
Maintain sinus rhythm (treat arrhythmias aggressively)
Cardioversion/defibrillation equipment immediately available
Full CPB anticoagulation
ICU postoperative with prolonged mechanical ventilation expected

surgical_type: Cardiac - Maze procedure for atrial fibrillation

teaching_points: AFib eliminates atrial kick, reducing cardiac output by 15-20%
Irregular ventricular response in AFib reduces cardiac efficiency
COPD causes pulmonary hypertension and RV strain
Limited cardiac reserve from both AFib and pulmonary disease
Maze procedure creates controlled scar tissue to interrupt reentrant circuits
Advanced age (76) reduces physiologic reserve and increases perioperative risk
COPD increases postoperative pulmonary complications after cardiac surgery
Pulmonary hypertension from COPD affects RV function and CPB management
Optimize bronchodilator therapy preoperatively
Assess hypoxemia and hypercarbia baseline status
May require prolonged postoperative mechanical ventilation
Minimize opioid doses to allow early extubation (difficult with COPD)
Optimize pulmonary mechanics on CPB (lung protection strategies)
May convert to sinus rhythm intraoperatively - monitor for rate changes
COPD patients benefit from early extubation but may need prolonged ventilation
Aggressive pulmonary toilet postoperatively

anesthetic_considerations: High-dose opioid technique balanced with need for early extubation
Bronchodilators available and administered preoperatively
Avoid histamine-releasing drugs
Monitor for conversion to sinus rhythm during procedure
Careful fluid management (avoid volume overload with limited cardiac/pulmonary reserve)
CPB management: minimize inflammatory response
Plan for possible prolonged mechanical ventilation postoperatively
ICU admission mandatory

teaching_points: Four-vessel CABG indicates extensive coronary disease
Strong heart (good EF) indicates preserved LV systolic function despite CAD
Type A personality associated with CAD and hypertension
Myocardial oxygen demand = HR × SBP (rate-pressure product)
Coronary blood flow occurs primarily in diastole
Well-controlled hypertension reduces perioperative risk

topics: Cardiac risk assessment with preserved function
teaching_points: CAD + high-risk surgery = elevated RCRI score
Good functional status improves prognosis despite extensive CAD
Continue beta-blockers and statins perioperatively
Well-controlled hypertension reduces risk of perioperative BP lability
Younger age (59) and good function are favorable prognostic factors
High-dose opioid technique standard for CABG
Maintain hemodynamic stability (avoid tachycardia and hypotension)
Internal mammary artery graft increases operative time but improves long-term patency
CPB duration typically 90-120 minutes for 4-vessel CABG
Early extubation protocols feasible with good cardiac function
Fast-track cardiac anesthesia appropriate for low-risk patients

anesthetic_considerations: Standard cardiac anesthetic induction (etomidate or propofol)
High-dose opioid technique (fentanyl 10-15 mcg/kg)
Maintain heart rate 60-80 bpm
Aggressive BP control perioperatively
Full CPB anticoagulation
Cardioplegia for myocardial protection
Fast-track extubation protocol (extubate in OR or within 6 hours)
ICU admission with plan for early extubation

teaching_points: CKD stage 3 affects drug clearance and perioperative morbidity
Volume overload from CHF and renal insufficiency complicates management
Combined CABG + valve increases operative time, CPB duration, and risk
Diabetes with renal disease indicates microvascular complications
Obesity increases cardiac workload and complicates surgical access
Multiple RCRI risk factors: CAD, CHF, diabetes, renal insufficiency
CKD stage 3 (GFR 30-59) increases AKI risk postoperatively
Volume assessment challenging (volume overload but may be intravascularly depleted)
Avoid nephrotoxic drugs perioperatively
Risk of dialysis requirement postoperatively
Longer CPB time increases inflammatory response and complications
Maintain adequate renal perfusion pressure during CPB (MAP >60-70)
Use cisatracurium (Hoffman elimination, not renally cleared)
Avoid NSAIDs postoperatively
Monitor for contrast-induced nephropathy if cardiac cath performed
Fluid management critical: avoid both hypovolemia and volume overload

anesthetic_considerations: Optimize volume status preoperatively (may need dialysis)
Etomidate or midazolam/fentanyl induction for hemodynamic stability
High-dose opioid technique
Use cisatracurium for neuromuscular blockade
Avoid renally-cleared drugs (morphine, meperidine)
Maintain adequate perfusion pressure during CPB
Expect longer CPB time (3+ hours possible)
Plan for prolonged mechanical ventilation
ICU admission with possible dialysis needs postoperatively

teaching_points: Aortic aneurysm repair requires cross-clamping with major hemodynamic changes
Cross-clamp increases afterload dramatically (LV must pump against closed aorta)
Release of cross-clamp causes sudden decrease in afterload and third-spacing
Previous stroke indicates cerebrovascular disease and increased perioperative stroke risk
Carotid stenosis reduces cerebral blood flow reserve
Maintain cerebral perfusion pressure (CPP = MAP - ICP)
Assess aneurysm size, location (thoracic vs abdominal), extent
Carotid stenosis >70% may require staged or combined CEA
Previous stroke increases perioperative stroke risk significantly
Hypertension must be controlled preoperatively
High risk of rupture if aneurysm >5.5 cm or symptomatic
Before cross-clamp: optimize preload, consider vasodilators ready
During cross-clamp: control hypertension (nitroglycerin, nicardipine), monitor for myocardial ischemia
After cross-clamp release: volume loading, vasopressors ready, expect hypotension
Spinal cord ischemia risk with thoracoabdominal aneurysms (monitor SSEPs/MEPs)
Maintain adequate perfusion pressure for cerebral and spinal cord protection
Consider lumbar drain for thoracoabdominal repairs

anesthetic_considerations: Large bore IV access for rapid transfusion capability
Arterial line before induction (bilateral for thoracic aneurysm)
Controlled hypotension before cross-clamp if not ruptured
Vasodilators ready (nitroglycerin, nicardipine, esmolol)
Volume loading before cross-clamp release
Vasopressors ready for post-release hypotension
Blood products available (anticipate significant blood loss)
Maintain normothermia (coagulopathy risk)
Spinal cord protection strategies for thoracoabdominal
ICU admission with mechanical ventilation

teaching_points: Atrial fibrillation increases stroke risk 5-fold, requiring anticoagulation
Cardiac catheterization used for diagnostic coronary angiography and interventions
Osteoporosis increases risk of positioning injury and vascular complications
Advanced age (78) reduces cardiovascular reserve and baroreceptor function
Anticoagulation must be managed carefully for catheterization access site
Hold warfarin before procedure (INR <1.8 acceptable for cath)
Bridge anticoagulation may be needed for high-risk AFib
Contrast-induced nephropathy risk (hydration important)
Vascular access complications: bleeding, hematoma, pseudoaneurysm
Conscious sedation vs monitored anesthesia care
Conscious sedation with midazolam and fentanyl typical
Maintain spontaneous ventilation and airway reflexes
Monitor for chest pain (myocardial ischemia during procedure)
Vasovagal reactions common during femoral access
Have vasopressors available (atropine, phenylephrine)
Post-procedure: bedrest for hemostasis, monitor access site

anesthetic_considerations: Light to moderate sedation (maintain verbal contact)
Midazolam 1-2 mg and fentanyl 25-50 mcg titrated carefully
Reduced doses in elderly (increased sensitivity)
Local anesthesia at access site (lidocaine)
Treat vasovagal reactions (atropine 0.5-1 mg IV)
Hydration for renal protection (contrast nephropathy prevention)
Gentle positioning (osteoporosis)
Post-procedure monitoring in recovery area

teaching_points: Redo cardiac surgery has significantly higher risk than primary surgery
Scarred pericardium and adhesions increase risk of cardiac injury during sternotomy
Previous CABG grafts may be patent, occluded, or diseased (target for redo)
COPD increases pulmonary complications and prolonged ventilation risk
Advanced age (73) with multiple comorbidities = very high risk
Review previous operative report: prior grafts, difficulties, complications
CT scan of chest assesses proximity of heart/vessels to sternum
Higher risk of catastrophic bleeding during redo sternotomy
Pulmonary function testing important with COPD history
Mortality risk 2-3x higher than primary CABG
Femoral cannulation access prepared before sternotomy (emergency CPB)
Defibrillator pads placed before induction
Cell saver mandatory (blood conservation)
Surgeon may dissect femoral vessels first for emergency access
Longer operative time due to adhesiolysis
Increased bleeding risk from scarred tissue
May require prolonged mechanical ventilation postoperatively

anesthetic_considerations: Large bore IV access before induction (rapid transfusion capability)
Blood products in room before sternotomy (cross-matched 6+ units)
Defibrillator pads placed before draping
Femoral vessels may be exposed for emergency cannulation
High-dose opioid technique
Anticipate longer CPB time
Aggressive blood conservation strategies
Plan for prolonged mechanical ventilation
ICU admission with high monitoring level

teaching_points: Percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) with stenting is less invasive than CABG
Small coronary vessels in Asian populations may affect stent sizing and technique
Diabetes accelerates coronary atherosclerosis and microvascular disease
Dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) required after stent placement
Drug-eluting stents require longer DAPT duration than bare metal stents
Continue aspirin perioperatively for PCI
Clopidogrel or ticagrelor typically continued (or held 24 hours if loading dose given)
Elective surgery should be delayed after stenting: BMS 30 days minimum, DES 6-12 months
Premature discontinuation of DAPT increases stent thrombosis risk
Conscious sedation adequate for most PCI procedures
Light sedation allows patient to report chest pain (ischemia indicator)
Contrast dye used for angiography (renal protection important)
Complications: coronary dissection, perforation, no-reflow phenomenon, acute stent thrombosis
Emergency CABG backup required (rare but critical complication)
Radial artery access increasingly common (lower bleeding risk than femoral)

anesthetic_considerations: Light conscious sedation (midazolam 1-2 mg, fentanyl 25-50 mcg)
Patient able to report symptoms during procedure
Antiplatelet therapy continued (aspirin, possibly P2Y12 inhibitor)
Hydration for contrast nephropathy prevention
Heparin anticoagulation during procedure (ACT 200-250 seconds)
Nitroglycerin available for coronary vasospasm
Monitor for chest pain, ST changes (ischemia indicators)
Post-procedure: bedrest, access site monitoring, DAPT education

teaching_points: GCS 8 indicates severe TBI (GCS ≤8 = coma, requires intubation)
Maintain cerebral perfusion pressure: CPP = MAP - ICP (goal CPP >60 mmHg)
Avoid hypotension (SBP <90 mmHg doubles mortality in TBI)
Avoid hypoxia and hypercarbia (increase ICP and worsen secondary brain injury)
Intracranial hypertension reduces cerebral blood flow and causes herniation
RSI technique mandatory (full stomach risk in trauma)
Primary survey: Airway, Breathing, Circulation, Disability, Exposure (ABCDE)
Rib fractures may indicate pulmonary contusion or pneumothorax
Hemodynamic instability suggests ongoing hemorrhage (search for source)
CT brain essential for TBI: location, size, midline shift, herniation
Associated cervical spine injury in 5-10% of severe TBI (inline stabilization)
Normal ICP is 5-15 mmHg; treatment threshold typically >20-22 mmHg
Cerebral autoregulation may be impaired in TBI (CBF becomes pressure-dependent)
Hyperventilation reduces ICP but causes cerebral vasoconstriction (temporary measure only)
Avoid hypocapnia <30 mmHg (may cause cerebral ischemia)
Hypertonic saline or mannitol for ICP reduction
Maintain normothermia (fever increases metabolic demand and ICP)

anesthetic_considerations: RSI with cricoid pressure: etomidate 0.3 mg/kg or ketamine 1-2 mg/kg, rocuronium 1-1.2 mg/kg
Avoid hypotension during induction (maintain SBP >100 mmHg, MAP >80)
Avoid succinylcholine if >24 hours post-injury (hyperkalemia risk)
Maintain PaCO2 35-40 mmHg (mild hyperventilation only if acute herniation)
Head of bed elevated 30 degrees (after cervical spine cleared)
Osmotherapy available: mannitol 0.25-1 g/kg or hypertonic saline 3% bolus
Avoid hypotonic fluids (use isotonic crystalloids: NS or LR)
Maintain normothermia (forced air warmer)
Total IV anesthesia vs balanced technique (avoid nitrous oxide)
Plan for postoperative mechanical ventilation and ICP monitoring in ICU

surgical_type: Trauma - Emergency exploratory laparotomy for GSW

teaching_points: Hemorrhagic shock classification: Class III (30-40% blood loss) or Class IV (>40%)
Penetrating abdominal trauma has high risk of vascular, solid organ, and hollow viscus injury
Massive transfusion protocol: balanced resuscitation with blood products
Damage control surgery: control hemorrhage, limit contamination, abbreviated operation
Avoid crystalloid-only resuscitation (dilutional coagulopathy, hypothermia, acidosis)
Lethal triad: hypothermia, acidosis, coagulopathy
ATLS protocols: permissive hypotension until hemorrhage control (SBP 80-90 mmHg)
Massive transfusion = replacement of entire blood volume in 24 hours
Balanced transfusion ratio: RBC:FFP:platelets = 1:1:1
FAST exam identifies free intraperitoneal fluid (blood)
Type O negative blood for life-threatening hemorrhage (universal donor)
Activate massive transfusion protocol early
Compensatory mechanisms in shock: tachycardia, vasoconstriction, increased contractility
Decompensated shock: hypotension, obtundation, organ dysfunction
Acidosis impairs coagulation cascade and platelet function
Hypothermia <35°C worsens coagulopathy
Hypocalcemia from citrate in blood products (supplement calcium)
Tranexamic acid within 3 hours may reduce mortality in trauma hemorrhage

monitoring_needs: Arterial line before or immediately after induction
anesthetic_considerations: Massive transfusion protocol activated before OR
Large bore IV access (14-16 gauge x2) or central venous introducer
Rapid infuser and blood warmer setup
Modified RSI: ketamine 1-2 mg/kg or etomidate 0.2-0.3 mg/kg (reduced doses in shock)
Avoid propofol in hemodynamically unstable patients (vasodilation)
Succinylcholine 1.5 mg/kg or rocuronium 1.2 mg/kg for RSI
Permissive hypotension until hemorrhage control (MAP 60-65 mmHg)
Balanced transfusion: 1:1:1 ratio RBC:FFP:platelets
Tranexamic acid 1g load then 1g over 8 hours (if <3 hours from injury)
Calcium chloride 1g for every 4-5 units blood products
Aggressive warming: forced air warmer, fluid warmer, increase OR temperature
Damage control resuscitation: abbreviate surgery if unstable, return to ICU
Plan for ICU with possible return to OR for definitive repair

teaching_points: Bilateral femur fractures cause significant blood loss (500-1500 mL per fracture)
Fall from height suggests high-energy trauma (assess for other injuries)
Pneumothorax managed with chest tube before anesthesia
Fat embolism syndrome risk with long bone fractures (24-72 hours post-injury)
Young patients tolerate blood loss better but still require volume resuscitation
Chest tube management: ensure functional and no air leak before anesthesia
Pneumothorax risk of tension if positive pressure ventilation
Pain control important but avoid oversedation in trauma
Long bone fractures stabilized early reduce pulmonary complications
Type and cross for potential transfusion
Femur fractures can cause 1-2 liter blood loss into thigh (closed fracture)
Fat embolism: fat droplets enter circulation, can cause ARDS and neurologic changes
Early fracture stabilization reduces fat embolism risk
Adolescents have good cardiovascular reserve but require careful monitoring
Maintain adequate perfusion and oxygenation

anesthetic_considerations: Assess chest tube function before induction (no air leak, lung expanded)
RSI if recent food intake or altered mental status
Standard induction if >8 hours NPO and alert
Adequate IV access for volume resuscitation (16-18 gauge x2)
Blood products available (type and cross 2-4 units)
Regional anesthesia consideration: femoral nerve blocks for postoperative analgesia
General anesthesia standard for bilateral long bone fractures
Multimodal analgesia: regional blocks, acetaminophen, NSAIDs (if no contraindication), opioids
Monitor for fat embolism signs: hypoxia, tachycardia, mental status changes, petechiae
Maintain normothermia (long procedure)
Plan for postoperative pain management and early mobilization

teaching_points: Neurogenic shock: loss of sympathetic tone causes hypotension and bradycardia
Spinal cord injury level determines neurologic deficits and autonomic dysfunction
C-spine injury requires inline stabilization during intubation
Differentiate neurogenic shock from hemorrhagic shock (warm extremities, bradycardia vs tachycardia)
High cervical injuries (C1-C4) may require mechanical ventilation (phrenic nerve C3-C5)
Vasopressor support needed for neurogenic shock (loss of SVR)
ASIA (American Spinal Injury Association) scale: motor and sensory level assessment
Complete vs incomplete spinal cord injury (presence of sacral sparing)
C-spine fracture requires inline stabilization at all times
Rule out other injuries: head trauma, thoracic injuries, intra-abdominal bleeding
Baseline neurologic exam critical for postoperative comparison
Sympathetic outflow T1-L2; injury above T6 causes profound autonomic dysfunction
Loss of sympathetic tone: vasodilation (hypotension), unopposed vagal tone (bradycardia)
Spinal shock: temporary loss of all reflexes below injury level (hours to weeks)
Autonomic dysreflexia risk in chronic SCI above T6 (not acute phase)
Require vasopressors (phenylephrine or norepinephrine) and fluid resuscitation

anesthetic_considerations: Inline stabilization for all airway maneuvers (manual inline stabilization, not hard collar)
Consider awake fiberoptic intubation if unstable C-spine or difficult airway predicted
RSI with inline stabilization if patient stable and airway straightforward
Avoid succinylcholine after 24-48 hours post-injury (hyperkalemia risk from denervation)
Vasopressor infusion before induction (norepinephrine or phenylephrine)
Treat bradycardia with atropine or glycopyrrolate
Maintain MAP 85-90 mmHg for spinal cord perfusion (first 7 days post-injury)
Methylprednisolone controversial (not routinely recommended per current guidelines)
Avoid hypotension (worsens spinal cord ischemia)
Plan for postoperative mechanical ventilation if high cervical injury
ICU admission with close hemodynamic monitoring

teaching_points: Unstable pelvic fractures cause massive retroperitoneal hemorrhage (can lose liters of blood)
Motorcycle accidents = high-energy trauma (assess for multisystem injuries)
Pelvic binder applied early reduces pelvic volume and tamponades bleeding
Angiographic embolization may be needed for arterial bleeding
Ongoing blood loss indicates need for aggressive resuscitation and possible angiography
Pelvic fracture stability: lateral compression, AP compression, vertical shear
Unstable fractures (AP compression, vertical shear) have higher bleeding risk
FAST exam may miss retroperitoneal blood (CT more sensitive)
Activate massive transfusion protocol for hemodynamically unstable pelvic fractures
External fixation provides temporary stability, reduces pain, aids hemostasis
Retroperitoneal space can hold several liters of blood before tamponade
Venous bleeding more common than arterial (managed with pelvic binder and fixation)
Arterial bleeding requires angiographic embolization
Permissive hypotension controversial in pelvic fractures (may worsen bleeding if arterial)
Balanced resuscitation with blood products maintains oxygen delivery and coagulation

monitoring_needs: Large bore IV x2 or central introducer
Blood gases and coagulation studies frequently
Foley catheter (contraindicated if urethral injury suspected)
anesthetic_considerations: Massive transfusion protocol activated
Large bore IV access (14-16 gauge x2) or 8.5 Fr introducer
Blood products immediately available (O negative if unstable)
Modified RSI with reduced induction doses (ketamine 0.5-1 mg/kg or etomidate 0.1-0.2 mg/kg)
Vasopressor support (norepinephrine or phenylephrine infusion)
Permissive hypotension until binder applied and fracture stabilized (MAP 60-65)
Balanced transfusion 1:1:1 ratio RBC:FFP:platelets
Tranexamic acid 1g load then infusion
Calcium supplementation (1g per 4-5 units blood)
Aggressive temperature management (warmer, fluid warmer, room temperature up)
May need angiographic embolization before or after OR stabilization
Damage control approach: stabilize, control bleeding, ICU for resuscitation
Plan for ICU with continued resuscitation

teaching_points: Penetrating chest trauma can injure heart, great vessels, lungs, esophagus, diaphragm
Hemothorax = blood in pleural space (impairs ventilation and causes hemorrhagic shock)
Chest tube output >1500 mL immediately or >200 mL/hr indicates thoracotomy
Stab wounds have better prognosis than gunshot wounds (less tissue destruction)
Cardiac tamponade possible with wounds near heart (Beck's triad: hypotension, JVD, muffled heart sounds)
FAST exam or pericardial window if cardiac injury suspected
Chest X-ray shows hemothorax, pneumothorax, mediastinal widening
Chest tube placement therapeutic and diagnostic (measures ongoing blood loss)
Emergency thoracotomy indicated for: massive hemothorax, persistent bleeding, cardiac arrest
Type and cross multiple units (potential for massive hemorrhage)
Positive pressure ventilation can worsen pneumothorax (tension pneumothorax)
Ensure chest tube functional before induction
One-lung ventilation may be needed for surgical exposure
Hypoxic pulmonary vasoconstriction maintains V/Q matching during OLV
Blood in chest reduces lung compliance and functional residual capacity

anesthetic_considerations: Assess chest tube output and function before induction
Large bore IV access x2 (potential for rapid hemorrhage)
Blood products in room (cross-matched 4-6 units minimum)
RSI standard (penetrating trauma = full stomach)
Ketamine 1-2 mg/kg or etomidate 0.3 mg/kg for induction
Avoid nitrous oxide (expands pneumothorax)
Left-sided double-lumen tube or bronchial blocker for one-lung ventilation if needed
Prepare for possible cardiac injury: have pericardial instruments available
Cell saver for blood conservation
Maintain adequate preload and cardiac output
Plan for postoperative mechanical ventilation if significant lung injury
ICU admission postoperative

teaching_points: Facial trauma creates difficult airway: distorted anatomy, bleeding, edema, fractures
Jaw fractures may prevent mouth opening (trismus, mechanical obstruction)
Blood in airway increases aspiration risk and obscures visualization
Nasal intubation contraindicated with midface fractures (risk of intracranial placement)
Assault victims may have cervical spine injury (10% with maxillofacial trauma)
Assess airway: mouth opening, tongue mobility, bleeding, missing teeth
Clear C-spine before manipulation if possible (CT, clinical clearance)
Facial fractures classified: mandible, maxilla (Le Fort I, II, III), zygoma, nasal
Le Fort fractures indicate high-impact trauma (intracranial injury possible)
Full stomach assumed in all trauma patients
Maxillofacial fractures distort normal airway landmarks
Bleeding and secretions pool in pharynx (suction essential)
Edema worsens over time (secure airway early)
Aspiration of blood causes chemical pneumonitis and hypoxemia
Shared airway with surgeon requires coordination and secured ETT

anesthetic_considerations: Difficult airway cart in room before induction
Awake fiberoptic intubation strongly considered (safest option)
Alternative: video laryngoscopy with inline C-spine stabilization
RSI risky with difficult airway (can't intubate, can't ventilate scenario)
Oral intubation preferred (nasal contraindicated with midface fractures)
Suction immediately available (clear blood and secretions)
Consider tracheostomy if severe facial injuries or prolonged surgery
ETT secured with wires or sutures (tape ineffective with facial surgery)
Throat pack placement (prevent blood aspiration)
Careful extubation: assess airway patency, edema, ensure patient fully awake
ICU observation if airway edema concerns

teaching_points: 35% TBSA burns = major burn injury requiring ICU care and massive fluid resuscitation
Smoke inhalation causes airway edema, bronchospasm, carbon monoxide poisoning
Airway edema worsens over first 24-48 hours (early intubation critical)
Burn shock: massive fluid shifts from intravascular to interstitial space
Parkland formula: 4 mL/kg × %TBSA burn × body weight (half in first 8 hours)
Escharotomy relieves compartment syndrome from circumferential burns
Burn severity: depth (1st, 2nd, 3rd degree) and extent (%TBSA)
Rule of nines: head/neck 9%, each arm 9%, each leg 18%, torso front/back 18% each
Smoke inhalation indicators: facial burns, singed nasal hairs, carbonaceous sputum, hoarseness
Carbon monoxide poisoning: COHb levels, treat with 100% oxygen
Cyanide toxicity possible with enclosed space fires
Burn injury causes release of inflammatory mediators (histamine, bradykinin, prostaglandins)
Increased capillary permeability causes massive fluid loss and hypovolemia
Hypermetabolic state begins 48-72 hours post-burn (increased oxygen consumption)
Airway edema from direct thermal injury and fluid resuscitation
High risk of infection (loss of skin barrier, immunosuppression)

monitoring_needs: Foley catheter with hourly urine output goal 0.5-1 mL/kg/hr
anesthetic_considerations: Early intubation before airway edema worsens (secure airway immediately)
Large ETT (7.5-8.0 mm) to facilitate bronchoscopy and pulmonary toilet
RSI with ketamine 1-2 mg/kg (maintains hemodynamics, analgesia, bronchodilation)
Avoid succinylcholine if >24-48 hours post-burn (hyperkalemia from upregulated receptors)
100% oxygen for CO poisoning (reduces COHb half-life)
Aggressive fluid resuscitation: Parkland formula as starting point, titrate to urine output
Large bore IV access x2 (may need central access if peripheral burned)
Warming measures critical (massive heat loss from burns): warm fluids, forced air warmer, increase room temperature
Multimodal analgesia: opioid infusion, ketamine infusion, regional blocks if feasible
Escharotomy before general anesthesia if compromising ventilation or circulation
Plan for prolonged mechanical ventilation
ICU admission to burn unit

surgical_type: Trauma - Observation vs laparotomy for liver laceration

teaching_points: Blunt abdominal trauma causes solid organ injury: liver, spleen, kidneys
Grade 3 liver laceration: 3-10 cm depth, moderate severity
Non-operative management (NOM) preferred for hemodynamically stable patients
Rib fractures associated with liver and spleen injuries (lower ribs)
Serial exams, CT scans, and hemoglobin monitoring guide NOM vs surgery decision
Liver injury grading (I-VI): based on depth, length, and vascular involvement
NOM success rate high for grades I-III if hemodynamically stable
Surgery indicated for: hemodynamic instability, peritonitis, grade IV-V injuries, failed NOM
Type and cross blood (liver highly vascular, can bleed significantly)
Serial hemoglobin and CT monitoring for occult bleeding
Liver receives 25% of cardiac output (highly vascular organ)
Liver has dual blood supply: hepatic artery (25%) and portal vein (75%)
Most liver lacerations stop bleeding spontaneously with hemostasis
Monitor for delayed hemorrhage (can occur days after injury)
Emotional state (scared, crying) may indicate pain, fear, or physiologic stress

monitoring_needs: Arterial line if going to OR
anesthetic_considerations: If NOM: pain management with multimodal approach (avoid excessive sedation to allow serial exams)
If surgery needed: RSI (blunt trauma = full stomach)
Large bore IV x2 (potential for significant hemorrhage)
Blood products available (cross-matched 4-6 units)
Standard induction if stable (propofol or etomidate)
Cell saver for blood conservation
Damage control surgery if unstable: pack liver, temporary closure, ICU resuscitation
Definitive repair if stable: hemostasis, debridement, drainage
Postoperatively: ICU if surgery, floor with telemetry if NOM
Continue serial exams and hemoglobin monitoring

teaching_points: Alcohol intoxication complicates neurologic assessment (GCS unreliable)
Subdural hematoma: bleeding between dura and arachnoid, often from bridging veins
Acute SDH requires urgent evacuation if symptomatic or >10 mm thickness
Fall + head trauma + alcohol = high aspiration risk (depressed airway reflexes)
Combative patients at risk for self-injury and difficult airway management
Alcohol level may mask or mimic head injury symptoms
CT brain essential: SDH location, size, midline shift, mass effect
Assess for other injuries (fall patients often have rib, spine, extremity fractures)
Full stomach assumed (alcohol delays gastric emptying)
Coagulopathy possible if chronic alcohol use (liver dysfunction, low platelets)
SDH accumulates slowly, causes gradual ICP increase and brain compression
Evacuation can cause rapid decompression and rebleeding (controlled drainage)
Acute alcohol intoxication decreases anesthetic requirements (potentiates GABA)
Chronic alcohol use increases anesthetic requirements (enzyme induction, tolerance)
Alcohol withdrawal risk postoperatively (seizures, DTs)

anesthetic_considerations: RSI mandatory (full stomach + combative + head injury)
Adequate sedation before induction (avoid hypertension and combativeness during induction)
Ketamine OK for sedation (maintains hemodynamics, less respiratory depression)
Etomidate 0.3 mg/kg or propofol 1-2 mg/kg for induction (reduced doses if intoxicated)
Rocuronium 1-1.2 mg/kg for paralysis
Maintain CPP >60 mmHg (MAP - ICP)
Avoid hypertension during evacuation (risk of rebleeding)
Check coagulation and correct if abnormal (FFP, platelets if needed)
Maintain normocapnia (PaCO2 35-40 mmHg)
Benzodiazepine protocol for alcohol withdrawal prevention
Plan for postoperative mechanical ventilation and ICP monitoring
ICU admission with close neurologic monitoring
